question: How can swarm convert human signals into durable knowledge with less signal loss?
method: Programmatic audit of memory/HUMAN-SIGNALS.md: classify each entry by encoding depth (canonical L/P/F/B artifact vs. file-reference-only vs. workspace-only)
findings: Behavioral encoding rate ~98%: nearly all signals change a file or behavior
Knowledge encoding rate ~39%: only 37/102 table signals produce a canonical L/P/F/B artifact
The 64% gap = signals that produce behavioral change but no searchable/durable knowledge node
Paragraph-format signals (richer, authored) encode canonically at 67% vs 36% for table rows
High-specificity signals ('swarm competitions for humanity') → rich encoding; bare 'swarm' → file-ref only — expected and appropriate
Two signals have no artifact ref at all (S173 'swarm the human input too', S208 utilization signal)

gap_analysis.primary_gap: Table row format encourages terse 'Applied to X.md' entries; does not prompt lesson extraction
gap_analysis.secondary_gap: Pattern-section signals extracted as behavioral patterns but not always promoted to L/P
gap_analysis.tertiary_gap: Bare autonomy signals ('swarm') structurally produce no canonical artifact unless the session makes a notable discovery

recommendations: Per-signal prompt: after encoding, ask 'does this warrant a lesson or principle?' before logging
Periodic pattern promotion: scan 'Applied to' entries for reusable patterns → elevate to L/P
Bare-signal artifact rule: sessions responding to bare 'swarm' should produce at least one L/P if work was substantive
verdict: BASELINE ESTABLISHED: 36% canonical encoding (table), 67% (paragraphs). Target: >60% canonical across all formats.
